subject: Re: [junit] remove test from suite?
msgSnippet: ... the problem was with the cactus sample (a servlet testing framework that uses junit). there was one test class that had two of its test methods not
messageBody:
At 06:57 PM 2/14/02 -0800, you wrote:
> > hi, is there any easy way to remove a test from a suite? i am fooling
> > around with cactus and some of the tests are not implemented yet.
>
>
>If I read between the lines I can imagine that the only problem you may
>have is that a run failes and the error message is ""No tests found in
>..." (if it's not the problem, please give more infos)

the problem was with the cactus sample (a servlet testing framework that
uses junit). there was one test class that had two of its test methods not
implemented (emtpy method body). with these being no-ops, running the tests
failed with an error (not a failure). commenting these out let me run
the sample.

while removing a test may be contrary to the spirit of unit testing, it may
be necessary in some cases to make some progress. so i was looking for an
easy way to remove a few tests. maybe TestSuite should have a remove methor
or a constructor that takes a "exlude" list of methods.

>cause of this problem: classes that extend TestCase _must_ have at least
>one valid test method (public, void return, no arg and beginning with
>"test").
>
>Several solutions:
>
>...
>- find the testsuite that includes this class and remove the
>addTestSuite(myFaultyClass.class) call

unfortunately, the suite() method just returns a new TestSuite(name.class);

>- modify JUnit to implement a soft-error handling: if an error message
>starts with "xyz", consider this as a warning and not as an error (in
>TestResult).
>
> public void runProtected(final Test test, Protectable p) {
> try {
> p.protect();
> } catch (AssertionFailedError e) {
> if (e.getMessage().startsWith("No tests found in")) {
> System.out.println("warning " + e.getMessage());
> } else {
> addFailure(test, e);
> }
> } catch (ThreadDeath e) { // don't catch ThreadDeath by accident
> throw e;
> } catch (Throwable e) {
> addError(test, e);
> }
> }
>
>Did I mentioned that it was ugly? :-)

yes, it is ugly, but an interesting approach.

thanks
